thread.title: A complete list of 2015's Nobel Prize winners
thread.title_full: A complete list of 2015's Nobel Prize winners

author: courier-journal.com
title: A complete list of 2015's Nobel Prize winners
text:
Princeton's Angus Deaton wins Nobel economics prize for his study of consumer economics. VPC
This year's Nobel Prize winners, who created drugs to save lives and chronicled lives lost in great tragedies, will receive their awards from the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences on Dec. 10, the anniversary of prize founder Alfred Nobel's death in 1896. This year's recipients:
Irish-born William Campbell and Satoshi Omura and of Japan developed a drug that has reduced illnesses caused by parasitic worms.
Tu Youyou developed a drug that has significantly cut the number of deaths from malaria.
Takaaki Kajita of Japan and Arthur McDonald of Canada discovered neutrino oscillations. The academy said, "The discovery has changed our understanding of the innermost workings of matter and can prove crucial to our view of the universe."
Sweden's Tomas Lindahl , American Paul Modrich and U.S.-Turkish scientist Aziz Sancar will be honored for "mechanistic studies of DNA repair."
The academy said their work, which helped develop cancer treatments, "has provided fundamental knowledge of how a living cell functions."
Belarusian writer Svetlana Alexievich used the skills of a journalist to create literature chronicling the great tragedies of the Soviet Union and its collapse: World War II, the Soviet war in Afghanistan, the Chernobyl nuclear disaster and the suicides that ensued from the death of communism.
The Tunisia's National Dialogue Quartet won the Peace Prize for its efforts to bring democracy to the country, where the political upheaval in 2011 sparked pro-democracy movements throughout the Arab world. The academy praised the group "for its decisive contribution to the building of a pluralistic democracy in Tunisia in the wake of the Jasmine Revolution of 2011."
“It established an alternative, peaceful political process at a time when the country was on the brink of civil war,” the committee said.
The National Dialogue Quartet is made up of four organizations: the Tunisian General Labour Union ; Tunisian Confederation of Industry , Trade and Handicrafts ; Tunisian Human Rights League ; and Tunisian Order of Lawyers .
Scottish economist Angus Deaton, who now works at Princeton University, won for “his analysis of consumption, poverty, and welfare." Deaton is being honored for his work that revolves around three central questions: How do consumers distribute their spending among different goods; how much of society’s income is spent and how much is saved; and how do we best measure and analyze welfare and poverty?
USA TODAY research, Associated Press contributed to this report; graphics by Kevin Kepple, USA TODAY
